data.name: textBoxDescription.Text
data.value:
Wow. This program has a really long history. Anyway...
This program started out as "Back2Basics" (or B2B for short), an Ether program for the Alchemy OS (which is a virtual machine for the J2ME mobile platform) that I made sometime around February 2013. I wondered, "How would this image looked like if the C64 was showing it?" So I learned about color matching and dithering algorithms and stuff. It was sort of successful. Well, it did not consider the one fixed color of every tile in a real C64, nor did it consider the limited number of tiles that the memory can handle, nor did it consider the resolution of the targetted computer, or even the fact that the hi-color C64 mode had a wide pixel ratio, but it did create "believable" results since it limited the colors to four (or was it three) per 8x8 tile. Later, NES and ZX Spectrum modes were added, but because it was running on a 330MHz ARM Nokia N95, it started to run really slowly, and the code got really messy (since I was only using a single source code file). In the end, I regretted doing it all ("What a waste of code!", I thought) and deleted the executable from the net and the source code on my phone. (I later found out that there was still a copy of the source code that I still haven't deleted, and I kept it for historical purpose, but that's another story.) I made a new program from scratch, for Alchemy OS, called "Indexed", with the aim of converting images into indexed format (and in later versions, image analysis). It was fast since I wrote it carefully, but as before--is pretty much useless.
After I bought my first desktop computer (running Windows XP), I started programming in Java. I reimplemented it in Java, named "Back2Basics2". It now resizes the image to consider the target computer's screen resolution, and even keeps track of that one fixed tile color in a hi-res C64 image. It also observes the wide pixel ratio of the C64 in hi-color mode. It was also the first version to use LAB color space for color matching (previous versions used RGB color space) resulting in better conversions. However, it still doesn't consider the tile count limitation, and ignores that completely. Not to mention that it ran really slowly because color space conversion was a lot of math, and it was written in Java, and I only had a Pentium IV 3GHz as a CPU, and 512MB DDR RAM... Yeah...
Then when I bought my first laptop (now running Windows 10), I started programming in C#, and the sudden urge to revive my old program in C# gave birth to Back2Basics3. This contains all the previous features and more. It can now reduce the tile count! This routine took me some time to make--with the help of TaW from Stack Overflow. Thanks, TaW! :)
Well... There!
